fields.headline: 14th century boys
fields.bodyText: The Mapmakers John Noble Wilford (Pimlico, £12.50) Marvellous medievals 1: Cosmas's world was flat, with Jerusalem in the centre. Mapmaker Fra Mauro relocated the fabulous monarch Prester John in Africa - Marco Polo having testified that he wasn't in China, where he was supposed to dwell splendidly. The Peutinger Table, an 11th-century copy of a Roman strip map showing only the roads more travelled (the hell with the rest of the country) resembles early automobile route books ("turn left at the first red barn"). You could probably sail the African coast now with the 1351 Laurentian chart, and the 1375 Catalan Atlas added the Blue Nile, deleted monsters and only got vague around the Scots coast. Ace. Art & Beauty in the Middle Ages Umberto Eco (Yale, £8.50) Marvellous medievals 2: the mystics - St Hildegard seeing God burning in the sun and stars. The cathedral-builders - the skilled sculptors of Amiens chiselling statues deliberately distorted so that their proportions should appear harmonious to beholders 100ft below. The philosophers - John of Salisbury proposing that art and science allowed humanity to improve on nature, though nature remained the true source of energy. The inventors of modern aesthetic sensibility - Dante expressing "what love has commanded him from within". A world wholly recognisable, and all of it dated before 1400, so nuts to the High Renaissance.
